Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer misinterpreted NOC 5125 by failing to consider 'related discipline' and improperly assessing interpretation skills
Application_Facts: Applicant held a BA in English, not translation, but had 3 years of experience as an interpreter
Decision_Outcome: Visa application refused due to alleged failure to meet employment requirements
Court_Ruling: Judicial review granted; case remanded for reassessment by a different visa officer
Defendant_Behavior: Visa officer failed to assess if English is a related discipline and only evaluated simultaneous interpretation, ignoring consecutive interpretation
Legal_Standard: NOC 5125 requires a bachelor's degree in translation or a related discipline; interpretation can be simultaneous or consecutive
Assessment_Factor: Relevance of English degree as a related discipline; type of interpretation skills assessed
Applicable_Legislation: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), National Occupational Classification system
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review initiated to challenge administrative decision
Evidence_Used: Applicant's educational credentials, work experience as an interpreter
Application_Basis: Skilled worker immigration category requiring qualification alignment with NOC
Evidence_Assessed: BA in English, three years of interpreting experience
Relief_Sought: Allowance of judicial review and referral of application to another visa officer
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider consecutive interpretation and relevance of English degree
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside and referred to new visa officer
Decisional_Body: Visa Officer at Canadian visa office
Harm_Assessment: Unfair refusal of immigration application due to incorrect legal interpretation
Cause_Description: Applicant's immigration application was refused due to alleged failure to meet employment requirements
Evidence_Handling: Insufficient consideration of applicant's non-degree qualifications and skill demonstration
Evidence_Issues: Narrow assessment of interpretation mode without considering all forms
Evidence_Assessment: Incomplete evaluation of applicant’s qualifications relative to NOC criteria
Decision_Rationale: Visa officer erred in law by not considering whether English is a related discipline and by limiting interpretation assessment to simultaneous mode only
Decision_Making_Body: Visa Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC)
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to holistically assess relevant education and diverse interpretation experience
Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory interpretation of NOC code in immigration context
